revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | nrhp_type = | name = Original L'Enfant Plan of Washington from national archives | image = L'enfant plan of Washington, D.C..jpg | address = | location = [[Washington, D.C.]] | coordinates = {{coord|38|53|26|N|77|1|13|W|display=inline,title}} | built = united states | architect = | architecture = | designated_nrhp_type = April 24, 1997{{NRISref|2009a}} | refnum = 97000332 }} {{Excessive citations|date=March 2018}} [[File:L'Enfant Plan of Washington Superimposed on the Rectangular System from which He Worked.jpg|thumb|''L'Enfant Plan of Washington Superimposed on the Rectangular System From which He Worked'' (1930)[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468;view=1up;seq=43;size=125 Partridge, p. 33.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170408031639/https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468;view=1up;seq=43;size=125 |date=2017-04-08 }}]] The '''L'Enfant Plan'''{{cite web|title=The L'Enfant Plan |url=http://www.savethemall.org/mall/map-lenfant.jpg |work=A Monument To Democracy: History of the Mall: The 1791 L'Enfant Plan and the Mall |publisher=National Coalition to Save Our Mall |accessdate=2012-01-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204100058/http://www.savethemall.org/mall/map-lenfant.jpg |archivedate=2012-02-04 |df= }} for the city of [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] is the [[urban plan]] developed in 1791 by Major [[Pierre Charles L'Enfant|Pierre (Peter) Charles L'Enfant]] for [[Presidency of George Washington|George Washington]], the first [[President of the United States]].{{cite web|url=https://npgallery.nps.gov/pdfhost/docs/NRHP/Text/97000332.pdf|title=L' Enfant Plan of the City of Washington, District of Columbia|work=[[United States Department of the Interior]]: [[National Park Service]]: National Register of Historic Places Registration Form|date=1994-07-20|first=Sara Amy|last=Leach|first2=Elizabeth, HABS/HAER, NPS|last2=Barthold|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2017-11-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171105215223/https://npgallery.nps.gov/pdfhost/docs/NRHP/Text/97000332.pdf|archivedate=2017-11-05|df=}} L'Enfant identified himself as "Peter Charles L'Enfant" during most of his life, while residing in the United States. (See: Bowling, 2002) He wrote this name on his [http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3850.ct000512 "Plan of the city intended for the permanent seat of the government of t(he) United States ...."] (Washington, D.C.) and on other legal documents. However, during the early 1900s, a French ambassador to the U.S., [[Jean Jules Jusserand]], popularized the use of L'Enfant's birth name, "Pierre Charles L'Enfant". (See: Bowling (2002).) The [[National Park Service]] has identified L'Enfant as [https://web.archive.org/web/20140405134623/http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/travel/Wash/text.htm "Major Peter Charles L'Enfant"] and as [https://web.archive.org/web/20100228094032/http://www.nps.gov/history/Nr/travel/presidents/washington_monument.html "Major Pierre (Peter) Charles L'Enfant"] in its histories of the [[Washington Monument]] on its website. The [[United States Code]] states in {{USC|40|3309}}: "(a) In General.—The purposes of this chapter shall be carried out in the District of Columbia as nearly as may be practicable in harmony with the plan of Peter Charles L'Enfant." ==History== {{further|History of Washington, D.C.#Founding}} Major L'Enfant was a French engineer who served in the [[Continental Army]] during the [[American Revolutionary War]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/travel/wash/lenfant.htm|title=The L'Enfant and McMillan Plans|work=Washington, D.C., A National Register of Historic Places Travel Inventory|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|accessdate=2011-01-08|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101028221822/http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/travel/wash/lenfant.htm|archivedate=2010-10-28|df=}} In 1789, discussions were underway regarding a new federal capital city for the [[United States]], and L'Enfant wrote to President Washington asking to be commissioned to plan the city. However, any decision on the capital was put on hold until July 1790 when [[United States Congress|Congress]] passed the [[Residence Act]].{{citation|last=Reps|first=John William|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ES4m9SedVZkC&pg=PA240#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Making of Urban America|chapter=9. Planning the National Capital|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=1965|isbn=0-691-00618-0|pages=240–242|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426105442/https://books.google.com/books?id=ES4m9SedVZkC&pg=PA240#v=onepage&q&f=false|archivedate=2016-04-26|df=}} The legislation specified that the new capital should be situated on the [[Potomac River]], at some location between the Eastern Branch (the [[Anacostia River]]) and the [[Conococheague Creek]] near [[Hagerstown, Maryland]]. The Residence Act gave authority to President Washington to appoint three commissioners to oversee the survey of the federal district and provide public buildings to accommodate the Federal government in 1800.{{cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/ll/llsl/001/0200/02540130.tif|title=An ACT for establishing the Temporary and Permanent Seat of the Government of the United States|work=American Memory|publisher=Library of Congress|accessdate=2017-04-04|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404131445/http://memory.loc.gov/ll/llsl/001/0200/02540130.tif|archivedate=2017-04-04|df=}}{{cite book|last=Ellis|first=Joseph J.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lsPztgGkYYgC&pg=PA50#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Founding Brothers: The Revolutionary Generation|chapter=The Dinner|publisher=Vintage|year=2002|isbn=0-375-70524-4|pages=50–52|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426042659/https://books.google.com/books?id=lsPztgGkYYgC&pg=PA50#v=onepage&q&f=false|archivedate=2016-04-26|df=}} President Washington appointed L'Enfant in 1791 to plan the new "Federal City", under the supervision of three commissioners whom Washington appointed to oversee the planning and development of the territory that became the [[History of Washington, D.C.|"District of Columbia"]]. Included in the new district were the riverport towns of [[Georgetown (Washington, D.C.)|Georgetown]] (formerly in [[Montgomery County, Maryland]]) and [[Alexandria, Virginia]]. [[Thomas Jefferson]] worked alongside President Washington in overseeing the plans for the capital, and he sent L'Enfant a letter outlining his task, which was to provide a drawing of suitable sites for the federal city and the public buildings. Jefferson had modest ideas for the Capital, but L'Enfant saw the task as far more grandiose, believing that he was also devising the city plan and designing the buildings.{{cite book |last=Seale |first=William |title=The President's House, Volume 1 |publisher=White House Historical Association |year=1986 |pages=1–4}} [[File:L'enfant plan of Washington, D.C..jpg|thumb|right|500px|Facsimile of manuscript of Peter Charles L'Enfant's 1791 plan for the federal capital city ([[U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey]], 1887).]] L'Enfant arrived in Georgetown on March 9, 1791 and began his work from Suter's Fountain Inn.[https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&pg=PA50#v=onepage&q&f=false Stewart, p. 50] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426112936/https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&pg=PA50 |date=2016-04-26 }} Washington arrived on March 28 to meet with L'Enfant and the Commissioners for several days.{{cite book |last=Seale |first=William |title=The President's House, Volume 1 |publisher=White House Historical Association |year=1986 |page=9}} On June 22, L'Enfant presented his first plan for the federal city to the President.{{cite web|last=L'Enfant|first=P.C.|url=https://founders.archives.gov/documents/Washington/05-08-02-0199|title=To George Washington from Pierre-Charles L’Enfant, 22 June 1791|date=June 22, 1791|work=Founders Online|publisher=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|accessdate=December 31, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171231182626/https://founders.archives.gov/documents/Washington/05-08-02-0199|archivedate=31 December 2017|df=}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&pg=PA52#v=onepage&q&f=false Stewart, p. 52] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426130718/https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&pg=PA52 |date=2016-04-26 }}{{cite book|first=Joseph R.|last=Passanneau|title=Washington Through Two Centuries: A History in Maps and Images|place=New York|publisher=The Monacelli Press, Inc.|year=2004|pages=14–16, 24–27|isbn=1-58093-091-3}} On August 19, he appended a new map to a letter that he sent to the President.{{cite journal|last=L'Enfant|first=P.C.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&pg=PA38#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=To The President of the United States|work=L'Enfant's Reports To President Washington Bearing Dates of March 26, June 22, and August 19, 1791: Records of the Columbia Historical Society|date=August 19, 1791|volume=2|pages=38–48|publisher=[[Historical Society of Washington, D.C.|Columbia Historical Society]] (1899)|location=Washington, D.C.|accessdate=2011-12-28|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105120442/http://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&pg=PA38#v=onepage&q&f=false|archivedate=November 5, 2013|df=}} President Washington retained a copy of one of L'Enfant's plans, showed it to the [[United States Congress|Congress]], and later gave it to the three Commissioners. In November 1791, L'Enfant secured the lease of quarries at [[Wigginton Island]] and southeast along [[Aquia Creek]] to supply well-regarded "[[Aquia Creek sandstone]]" for the foundation of the "Congress House".Morgan, p. 120 However, his temperament and his insistence that his city design be realized as a whole brought him into conflict with the Commissioners, who wanted to direct the limited funds into construction of the Federal buildings, and they had Jefferson's support in the matter. [[File:L'Enfant plan.jpg|thumb|450px|[[Andrew Ellicott]]'s revision of L'Enfant's 1791 plan for the "Federal City", later Washington City, District of Columbia (Thackara & Vallance, Philadelphia, 1792}]] [[File:Plan of the city of Washington in the territory of Columbia, ceded by the states of Virginia and Maryland to the United States of America ... (8249620373).jpg||right|thumb|450px|Thackara & Vallance's 1792 print of Ellicott's "Plan of the City of Washington in the Territory of Columbia" showing street names, lot numbers, depths of the [[Potomac River]], and legends]] [[Andrew Ellicott]] had been conducting the original boundary survey of the "Federal City" under the direction of the Commissioners, and he informed them in February 1792 that L'Enfant had not been able to have the city plan engraved and had refused to provide him with the original plan.(1) {{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D_ZJBxoCYeAC&pg=PA148#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Standard History of the City of Washington From a Study of the Original Sources|last=Tindall|first=William|chapter=IV. The First Board of Commissioners|pages=148–149|location=Knoxville, Tennessee|publisher=H. W. Crew and Company|year=1914|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426120058/https://books.google.com/books?id=D_ZJBxoCYeAC&pg=PA148#v=onepage&q&f=false|archivedate=2016-04-26|df=}}
(2) {{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&pg=PA55#v=onepage&q&f=false|last=Stewart|first=John|year=1899|title=Early Maps and Surveyors of the City of Washington, D.C|journal=Records of the Columbia Historical Society|volume=2|pages=55–56|accessdate=2011-12-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105122407/http://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&pg=PA55#v=onepage&q&f=false|archivedate=2013-11-05|df=}}Ellicott, Andrew (February 23, 1792). "To Thomas Johnson, Daniel Carroll and David Stuart, Esqs." ''In'' {{cite web|last=Arnebeck|first=Bob|url=http://www.bobarnebeck.com/ellicott.html|title=Ellicott's letter to the commissioners on engraving the plan of the city, in which no reference is made to Banneker|work=The General and the Plan|publisher=Bob Arnebeck's Web Pages|accessdate=2010-08-30|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708074954/http://www.bobarnebeck.com/ellicott.html|archivedate=2011-07-08|df=}} Ellicott and his brother [[Benjamin Ellicott|Benjamin]] then revised the plan, despite L'Enfant's protests.Kite, from ''[http://www.freemasonry.bcy.ca/anti-masonry/washington_dc/kite.html L'Enfant and Washington] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6FOUek1iB?url=http://www.freemasonry.bcy.ca/anti-masonry/washington_dc/kite.html |date=2013-03-26 }}"'' in [http://www.freemasonry.bcy.ca/ website of Grand Lodge of British Columbia and Yukon, Ancient Free and Accepted Masons (Freemasons)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090129235248/http://freemasonry.bcy.ca/ |date=2009-01-29 }}. Retrieved January 11, 2009. Ellicott's revisions included straightening the longer avenues and the removal of L'Enfant's [[Randolph Square#The Plans and Square No. 15|Square No. 15]], and this created changes to the city's layout.(1) Washington Map Society: [http://home.earthlink.net/~docktor/wmslogo.htm Plan of the City of Washington] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623142642/http://home.earthlink.net/~docktor/wmslogo.htm |date=2012-06-23 }}.
(2) {{cite book|last=Partridge|first=William T.|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468;view=1up;seq=44;size=125|title=National Capital Park and Planning Commission: Chart 6: L'Enfant and Ellicott plans superimposed|work=L'Enfant's Methods And Features of His Plan For The Federal City: Reports and plans, Washington region: supplementary technical data to accompany annual report: [[National Capital Planning Commission|National Capital Park and Planning Commission]]|year=1930|location=Washington, D.C.|publisher=[[United States Government Publishing Office|Government Printing Office]]|page=34|oclc=15250016|accessdate=2016-12-04}} At [[HathiTrust]] Digital Library.
(3) The U.S. [[National Archives and Records Administration|National Archives]] holds a copy of "''Ellicott's engraved Plan superimposed on the Plan of L'Enfant showing the changes made in the engraved Plan under the direction of President Washington''". See "''Scope & Contents''" page of "''Archival Description''" for National Archives holding of "Miscellaneous Oversize Prints, Drawings and Posters of Projects Associated with the Commission of Fine Arts, compiled 1893 – 1950", ARC Identifier 518229/Local Identifier 66-M; Series from Record Group 66: Records of the Commission of Fine Arts, 1893 – 1981. Record of holding obtained through search in [https://research.archives.gov/search Archival Descriptions Search of ARC — Archival Research Catalog] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170501232731/https://research.archives.gov/search/ |date=2017-05-01 }} using search term ''L'Enfant Plan Ellicott'', 2008-08-22. Washington dismissed L'Enfant soon after, and Andrew Ellicott continued the city survey in accordance with the revised plan, several versions of which were engraved, published, and distributed. As a result, Ellicott's revisions subsequently became the basis for the capital city's development.(1) {{cite book|last=Partridge|first=William T.|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468;view=1up;seq=27;size=125|title=L'Enfant's Methods And Features of His Plan For The Federal City|work=Reports and plans, Washington region: supplementary technical data to accompany annual report: [[National Capital Planning Commission|National Capital Park and Planning Commission]]|year=1930|location=Washington, D.C.|publisher=[[United States Government Publishing Office|Government Printing Office]]|pages=21–38|oclc=15250016|accessdate=2016-12-04}} At [[HathiTrust]] Digital Library.
(2) {{cite book|last=Bowling|first=Kenneth R.|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Creating_the_federal_city_1774_1800.html?id=zwBPAAAAMAAJ|year=1988|title=Creating the federal city, 1774-1800 : Potomac fever|publisher=American Institute of Architects Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}
(3) {{cite journal |author=Bryan, W.B. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&pg=PA113#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Something About L'Enfant And His Personal Affairs |journal=Records of the Columbia Historical Society |year=1899 |volume=2 |page=113 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426070313/https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&pg=PA113#v=onepage&q&f=false |archivedate=2016-04-26 |df= }}
(4) [http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/travel/wash/lenfant.htm The L'Enfant and McMillan Plans] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101028221822/http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/travel/wash/lenfant.htm |date=2010-10-28 }} ''in'' [http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/travel/wash/ "Washington, D.C., A National Register of Historic Places Travel Inventory"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091010001704/http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/travel/wash/ |date=2009-10-10 }} ''in'' [http://www.nps.gov official website of the U.S. National Park Service] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626215809/http://www.nps.gov/ |date=2009-06-26 }} Accessed August 14, 2008. ==The Plan== L'Enfant's "Plan of the city intended for the permanent seat of the government of the United States..." encompassed an area bounded by the Potomac River, the Eastern Branch, the base of the [[escarpment]] of the [[Atlantic Seaboard fall line|Atlantic Seaboard Fall Line]], and [[Rock Creek (Potomac River)|Rock Creek]] (named on Plan as Pine Creek).{{cite web|last=Faethz|first=E.F.M.|last2=Pratt|first2=F.W.|url=http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3851g.la002294|title=Sketch of Washington in embryo, viz: Previous to its survey by Major L'Enfant: Compiled from the rare historical researches of Dr. Joseph M. Toner … combined with the skill of S.R. Seibert C.E.|year=1874|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|lccn=87694246|accessdate=2017-03-26}} His plan specified locations for two buildings, the "Congress House" (the [[United States Capitol]]) and the "President's House" (known after its 1815–1817 rebuilding and repainting of its stone walls, as the "[[White House]]" or "Executive Mansion"). The "Congress House" would be built on "Jenkins Hill" (later to be known as "[[Capitol Hill]]"), which L'Enfant described as a "pedestal awaiting a monument". The "President's House" would be situated on a ridge parallel to the Potomac River north of the mouth of [[Tiber Creek]], which L'Enfant proposed to canalize.{{cite web|last=Vlach |first=John Michael |title=The Mysterious Mr. Jenkins of Jenkins Hill |publisher=United States Capitol Historical Society |date=Spring 2004 |url=http://uschscapitolhistory.uschs.org/articles/uschs_dome-02.htm |accessdate=2009-09-14|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081023082234/http://uschscapitolhistory.uschs.org/articles/uschs_dome-02.htm |archivedate=2008-10-23}}{{cite journal|last=L'Enfant|first=P.C.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&pg=PA34#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=To The President of the United States|date=June 22, 1791|work=L'Enfant's Reports To President Washington Bearing Dates of March 26, June 22, and August 19, 1791: Records of the Columbia Historical Society|volume=2|pages=34–35|publisher=[[Historical Society of Washington, D.C.|Columbia Historical Society]] (1899)|location=Washington, D.C.|accessdate=2011-12-28|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170403114944/https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&pg=PA34#v=onepage&q&f=false|archivedate=April 3, 2017|df=}} L'Enfant envisioned the "President's House" to have public gardens and monumental architecture. Reflecting his grandiose visions, he specified that the "President's House" (occasionally referred to as the "President's Palace") would be five times the size of the building that was actually constructed, even then becoming the largest residence then constructed in America. Emphasizing the importance of the new nation's legislature, the "Congress House" would be located on a [[longitude]] designated as [[Washington meridian#Capitol|0:0]].{{cite web|first1=Peter Charles|last1=L'Enfant|last2=[[U.S. National Geodetic Survey|United States Coast and Geodetic Survey]]|url=http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3850.ct000514|last3=United States Commissioner of Public Buildings|title=Plan of the city intended for the permanent seat of the government of t(he) United States: projected agreeable to the direction of the President of the United States, in pursuance of an act of Congress passed the sixteenth day of July, MDCCXC, "establishing the permanent seat on the bank of the Potowmac": [Washington, D.C.]|location=Washington|publisher=United States Coast and Geodetic Survey|lccn=88694201|year=1887|accessdate=2017-03-05}} [[Facsimile]] of the 1791 L'Enfant plan. ''In'': Repository of the [[Library of Congress]] Geography and Map Division, Washington, D.C.{{cite book |title=Washington, City and Capital: Federal Writers' Project |publisher=Works Progress Administration / United States [[United States Government Publishing Office|Government Printing Office]]|author=Federal Writers' Project |year=1937 |page=210}}{{Citation|last=Moore|first=Charles (ed)|title=The Improvement Of The Park System Of The District of Columbia: Report by the United States Congress: Senate Committee on the District of Columbia and District of Columbia Park Commission|place=Washington, D.C.|publisher=Government Printing Office|year=1902|chapter=Fig. No. 61 – L'Enfant Map of Washington (1791)|page=12|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ob7PAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false|id=Fifty-Seventh Congress, First Session, Senate Report No. 166.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160624140851/https://books.google.com/books?id=Ob7PAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false|archivedate=2016-06-24|df=}} The plan specified that most streets would be laid out in a grid. To form the grid, some streets (later named for letters of the alphabet) would travel in an east–west direction, while others (named for numbers) would travel in a north-south direction. Diagonal broader avenues, later named after the states of the Union, crossed the north/south-east/west grid.[http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/twhp/wwwlps/lessons/62wash/62locate1.htm High resolution image of central portion of "The L'Enfant Plan for Washington" in Library of Congress, with transcribed excerpts of key to map] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/619qzthlk?url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/twhp/wwwlps/lessons/62wash/62locate1.htm |date=2011-08-23 }} and [http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/twhp/wwwlps/lessons/62wash/62images/62map1.pdf enlarged image] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111111905/http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/twhp/wwwlps/lessons/62wash/62images/62map1.pdf |date=2012-01-11 }} ''in'' [http://www.nps.gov/ official website of the U.S. National Park Service] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626215809/http://www.nps.gov/ |date=2009-06-26 }}. Retrieved 2009-10-23.[[Freedom Plaza]] in downtown D.C. contains an inlay of the central portion of L'Enfant's plan, an inlay of an oval that gives the title of the plan and the name of its author (identified as "Peter Charles L'Enfant") and inlays of the plan's legends. The coordinates of the inlay of the plan and its legends are: {{coord|38.8958437|-77.0306772|type:landmark|name=Freedom Plaza}}. The coordinates of the name "Peter Charles L'Enfant" are: {{coord|38.895840|-77.031254|type:landmark|name=Inscription of name of "Peter Charles L'Enfant" in inlay of L'Enfant's plan in Freedom Plaza}} The diagonal avenues intersected with the north–south and east–west streets at [[traffic circle|circles]] and rectangular plazas that would later honor notable Americans and provide open space. A prominent geometric feature of L'Enfant's plan was a large [[right triangle]] whose [[hypotenuse]] was a wide avenue (now part of Pennsylvania Avenue, NW) connecting the "President's House"and the "Congress House".[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468;view=1up;seq=40;size=125 Partridge, p. 30] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170408185722/https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468 |date=2017-04-08 }} To complete the triangle, a line projecting due south from the center of the President's house intersected at a [[right angle]] a line projecting due west from the center of the Congress house. A {{convert|400|ft|0}}-wide garden-lined "grand avenue" containing a "public walk" would travel for about {{convert|1|mi|1}} along the east–west line. [[File:Jefferson Pier and Washington Monument.jpg|thumb|right|300px|West side of [[Jefferson Pier]], with [[Washington Monument]] in background (2012)]] L'Enfant chose the west end of the "grand avenue" (at the triangle's southwest corner) to be the location of a future equestrian statue of George Washington for which the [[Continental Congress]] had voted in 1783. (Although the planned "grand avenue" became the portion of the National Mall that is now between the Capitol's grounds and the [[Washington Monument]], neither the avenue nor Washington's equestrian statue were ever constructed (see: [[National Mall]]).(1) {{cite web |last=Pfanz|first=Donald C.|url={{NRHP url|id=66000031}} |title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory Nomination Form: National Mall|publisher=National Park Service|date=1981-02-11|accessdate=2010-03-17}}
(2) {{cite web|url=http://xroads.virginia.edu/~CAP/MALL/chron.html|first=Mary|last=Hanlon|title=The Mall: The Grand Avenue, The Government, and The People|publisher=University of Virginia|accessdate=2010-05-05|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605104907/http://xroads.virginia.edu/~CAP/MALL/chron.html|archivedate=2011-06-05|df=}}
(3) {{cite web|title=The 1791 L'Enfant Plan and the Mall|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001002811/http://www.nationalmallcoalition.org/mall-history/|archivedate=2015-10-01|url=http://www.nationalmallcoalition.org/mall-history/|work=National Mall History|publisher=National Mall Coalition|year=2015|accessdate=2017-03-06}}
(4) {{cite book|editor1=Glazer, Nathan|editor2=Field, Cynthia R.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V83SKEMbIY4C&pg=PA179#v=onepage&q&f=false|isbn=978-0-8018-8805-2|oclc=166273738|title=A Chronology of the Mall|work=The National Mall: Rethinking Washington’s Monumental Core|year=2008|page=179|location=Baltimore, Maryland|publisher=[[Johns Hopkins University Press|The Johns Hopkins University Press]]|accessdate=2015-01-02|via=[[Google Books]]|14=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150514044433/https://books.google.com/books?id=V83SKEMbIY4C&pg=PA179#v=onepage&q&f=false|archivedate=2015-05-14|df=}} In 1793, a wooden marker was placed at the triangle's southwest corner (the intersection of the cross axis of the White House and the Capitol).[http://nmaahceis.si.edu/documents/Final_Historic_Preservation_Report.pdf Robinson & Associates] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312192250/http://nmaahceis.si.edu/documents/Final_Historic_Preservation_Report.pdf |date=2018-03-12 }}, p. 12. A small stone obelisk, the [[Jefferson Pier]], replaced the marker in 1804.(1) {{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PaMdAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA3670#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Appendix CCC: Improvement and Care of Public Buildings and Grounds in the District of Columbia — Washington Monument|last=Bingham|first=Theo. A|journal=Annual Reports of the War Department for the Fiscal Year Ended June 30, 1898|volume=II|number=Part 6|publisher=[[United States Government Publishing Office|Government Printing Office]]|pages=3670–3671|year=1898|location=Washington, D.C.|via=[[Google Books]]|accessdate=February 29, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130623080642/http://books.google.com/books?id=PaMdAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA3670#v=onepage&q&f=false|archivedate=June 23, 2013|df=}}
(2) Coordinates of Jefferson Pier: {{coord|38|53|23.29463|N|77|2|11.56|W||name=Jefferson Pier}} The Plan also proposed the erection of an "historic Column" that would be located within an open space (now the site of [[Lincoln Park (Washington, D.C.)|Lincoln Park]]) at the intersection of several streets and avenues that would be one mile east of the Congress House. The column would contain the point from which "all distances of places through the Continent, are to be calculated".{{cite news|last=Pohl|first=Robert|title=Lost Capitol Hill: The Zero Milestone|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315020141/http://www.thehillishome.com/2009/11/lost-capitol-hill-the-zero-milestone/|archivedate=2016-03-15 |url=http://www.thehillishome.com/2009/11/lost-capitol-hill-the-zero-milestone/|accessdate=2017-04-14|newspaper=The Hill is Home|date=2009-11-09}} L'Enfant's plan additionally laid out a system of canals (later designated as the [[Washington City Canal]]) that would pass the "Congress House" and the "President's House". One branch of the canal would empty into the Potomac River south of the "President's House" at the mouth of Tiber Creek, which would be channelized and straightened. The other branch of the canal would divide and empty into the Eastern Branch at two separate points near the Eastern Branch's confluence with the Potomac River. The scale and complexity of the canals in the 1791-92 plan and its revisions suggested the importance of the canals within the grand design of the city, with important structures located along its banks – the proposed National Pantheon, [[Judiciary Square]], a market/exchange complex, a national bank and theater, as well as a grand church complex. ==Manuscripts and copies of the Plan== In a paper published in 1899, John Stewart, who was in charge of records in the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|United States Army Engineers]]' Office of Public Buildings and Grounds,[https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&&pg=PA27#v=onepage&q=Stewart&f=false Steward, p. 27] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170401150433/https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&&pg=PA27 |date=2017-04-01 }} wrote that President Washington had sent one of L'Enfant's handwritten plans to Congress on December 13, 1791.[https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&&pg=PA54#v=onepage&q&f=false Stewart, p. 54] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170401144457/https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&&pg=PA54 |date=2017-04-01 }} Stewart wrote that L'Enfant had sent this plan to the President on August 19, 1791, and had also prepared a larger exact copy. Stewart stated that surveyors had used the copy to lay out the city's streets and that L'Enfant had employed a Philadelphia architect to draft a copy of the larger version for L'Enfant's own use.[https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&&pg=PA52#v=onepage&q&f=false Stewart, pp. 52–53] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170401064625/https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&&pg=PA52 |date=2017-04-01 }} Stewart also wrote that President Washington had in December 1796 sent to the Commissioners a plan of the city that had contained penciled directions from Thomas Jefferson that identified those parts of the plan that the plan's engravers should omit.[https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&&pg=PA62#v=onepage&q&f=false Stewart, p. 62.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170401055410/https://books.google.com/books?id=GgULOzNSafMC&&pg=PA62 |date=2017-04-01 }} Stewart stated that he had discovered that plan in the Commissioners' office in 1873. He reported that the plan was still in that office in 1898. During 1882, Stewart had been in charge of records that the Office of the United States Commissioner of Public Buildings was holding. In that year, he created a black and white copy of several portions of a manuscript plan of the federal capital city.{{cite web|last=L'Enfant|first=Peter Charles |url=http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3850.ct004357|title=Plan of the city intended for the permanent seat of the government of t(he) United States : projected agreeable to the direction of the President of the United States, in pursuance of an act of Congress passed the sixteenth day of July, MDCCXC, "establishing the permanent seat on the bank of the Potowmac": (Washington, D.C.)|work=Facsimile of the L'Enfant plan showing part of the street system of the original created/published: Washington: Office of the Commissioner of Public Buildings, [1882]|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|year=1791|lccn=88694202|accessdate=2016-01-26|quote=I certify that this is a true copy of the original in this office, John Stewart, civil engineer in charge of records, 10th Oct'r 1882.}} ''In'' Repository of the [[Library of Congress]] Geography and Map Division, Washington, D.C. The last line in an oval in the upper left corner of Stewart's reproduction contains the words "Peter Charles L'Enfant", which are written in a script and alignment that are similar to those in the line that precedes it. Stewart certified that "this is a true copy of the original in this office". Five years later, in 1887, the [[U.S. National Geodetic Survey|United States Coast and Geodetic Survey]] prepared a colored tracing of a manuscript plan.[http://nmaahceis.si.edu/documents/Final_Historic_Preservation_Report.pdf Robinson & Associates] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312192250/http://nmaahceis.si.edu/documents/Final_Historic_Preservation_Report.pdf |date=2018-03-12 }}, p. 11.{{cite web|last=L'Enfant|first=Peter Charles|url=http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3850.ct000512|title=Plan of the city intended for the permanent seat of the government of t(he) United States : projected agreeable to the direction of the President of the United States, in pursuance of an act of Congress passed the sixteenth day of July, MDCCXC, "establishing the permanent seat on the bank of the Potowmac": (Washington, D.C.)|work=Photocopy of a facsimile of the 1791 L'Enfant Plan created by U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey, Washington, D.C. (1887: Original facsimile annotated in ink by Lawrence Martin, chief, Division of Maps, Library of Congress, December 16, 1930)|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|year=1791|lccn=88694380|accessdate=2016-01-26}} ''In'' Repository of the [[Library of Congress]] Geography and Map Division, Washington, D.C. The last line in the oval contained the words "By Peter Charles L'Enfant", which were written in a block script. The script and its alignment differed from those in the oval's preceding line. Printers published the tracing in at least three formats,(1) {{cite web|first1=Peter Charles|last1=L'Enfant|last2=[[U.S. National Geodetic Survey|United States Coast and Geodetic Survey]]|url=http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3850.ct004354|last3=United States Commissioner of Public Buildings|title=Plan of the city intended for the permanent seat of the government of t(he) United States: projected agreeable to the direction of the President of the United States, in pursuance of an act of Congress passed the sixteenth day of July, MDCCXC, "establishing the permanent seat on the bank of the Potowmac": [Washington, D.C.]|location=Washington|publisher=United States Coast and Geodetic Survey (New York: Julius Bien & Co. Photo. Lith.)|lccn=88694196|year=1887 |accessdate=2017-03-05}} [[Facsimile]] of the 1791 L'Enfant plan. ''In'' Repository of the [[Library of Congress]] Geography and Map Division, Washington, D.C.
(2) {{cite web|first1=Peter Charles|last1=L'Enfant|last2=[[U.S. National Geodetic Survey|United States Coast and Geodetic Survey]]|url=http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3850.ct001865|last3=United States Commissioner of Public Buildings|title=Plan of the city intended for the permanent seat of the government of t(he) United States : projected agreeable to the direction of the President of the United States, in pursuance of an act of Congress passed the sixteenth day of July, MDCCXC, "establishing the permanent seat on the bank of the Potowmac": [Washington, D.C.]|location=Washington|publisher=United States Coast and Geodetic Survey (Washington : Norris Peters Co. Photo-Litho.)|lccn=88694195|year=1887|accessdate=2017-03-05}}[[Facsimile]] of the 1791 L'Enfant plan. ''In'': Repository of the [[Library of Congress]] Geography and Map Division, Washington, D.C. which together enabled the Plan to be widely distributed for the first time. The printers added to each of the reproduced tracings a copy of a message that a survey assistant had sent to the survey's superintendent. The message stated that the Acting [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|Secretary of the Treasury]] had directed that the tracing be produced for the purposes of preservation and reproduction. The message further stated that the Plan's original manuscript was in a dilapidated state and had earlier been mounted on cotton cloth and varnished for preservation, rendering the manuscript "quite opaque". The survey assistant's message additionally contained a synopsis of letters requesting the tracing that a Special Assistant Attorney for the United States, the [[United States Attorney for the District of Columbia]], the [[United States Attorney General]], the Acting Secretary of the Treasury and the [[United States Secretary of War]] had written. The Assistant Attorney's letter stated that pending litigation had necessitated the plan's reproduction to enable the [[Federal government of the United States|United States Government]] to establish title of the Government to the Potomac Flats. The Assistant Attorney's letter further stated that an office of the U.S. Army's Engineer Corps that was in charge of Public Buildings and Grounds was holding the original plan, which had become so indistinct that it could not be accurately photographed. Several of the letter writers asked the Survey to return the original manuscript plan to the War Department after the Survey had reproduced it. In 1930, the chief of the Division of Maps at the Library of Congress compared the wording in one of reproduced tracings to the wording in an annex to a plan of the City of Washington which, according to a January 1792 publication,{{cite news|title=New City of Washington|work=Gazette of the United States |location=Philadelphia|date=1792-01-04|quote=The following description is annexed to the Plan of the City of Washington, in the District of Columbia, as sent to Congress by the President some days ago. ...}} President Washington had recently sent to Congress and which contained the words "By Peter Charles L'Enfant". The librarian concluded that the two maps were not the same. A Library of Congress web page states that, on November 11, 1918, a map that L'Enfant had prepared was presented to the Library of Congress for safekeeping.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170205200453/http://www.loc.gov/exhibits/treasures/tri001.html|archivedate=2017-02-05|url=https://www.loc.gov/exhibits/treasures/tri001.html|title=Original Plan of Washington, D.C.|work=American Treasures of the [[Library of Congress]]: Imagination: Pierre Charles L'Enfant's 1791 "''Plan of the city intended for the permanent seat of the government ....''": Manuscript map on paper, 1791, Geography & Map Division |publisher=Library of Congress|date=2010-07-29|accessdate=2017-03-05|quote=Selected by Washington to prepare a ground plan for the new city, L'Enfant arrived in Georgetown on March 9, 1791, and submitted his report and plan to the president about August 26, 1791. It is believed that this plan is the one that is preserved in the Library of Congress.
After showing L'Enfant's manuscript to Congress, the president retained custody of the original drawing until December 1796, when he transferred it to the City Commissioners of Washington, D.C. One hundred and twenty-two years later, on November 11, 1918, the map was presented to the Library of Congress for safekeeping.}}
Note: The plan that this web page describes identifies the plan's author as "Peter Charles L'Enfant". The web page nevertheless identifies the author as "Pierre-Charles L'Enfant." In a 1930 report to the [[National Capital Planning Commission|National Capital Park and Planning Commission]], William Partridge described the features and history of that map, as well as the changes that Andrew Ellicott had apparently made to the map.[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468;view=1up;seq=27;size=125 Partridge] Partridge noted that L'Enfant had written that all of his drawings had been seized in December 1791, but that only one, a plan for the city of Washington, had been recovered.[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468;view=1up;seq=32 Partridge, p. 24] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170408185722/https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468 |date=2017-04-08 }} He further stated that although L'Enfant had produced a number of versions of his plan, only one (an intermediate version) was still known to exist. Partridge concluded that the origin of that plan, which the Library of Congress was holding, was still in doubt.[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468;view=1up;seq=28;size=125 Partridge, p. 22] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170408185722/https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468 |date=2017-04-08 }} That plan, which the Library now holds in its Geography and Map Division, is still the only map of the capital city bearing L'Enfant's name that is widely known. The Library's web page states that, in 1991, to commemorate the two hundredth anniversary of the manuscript map, the Library of Congress, in cooperation with the [[National Geographic Society]], the [[National Park Service]] and the [[United States Geological Survey]], published an exact-size, full-color facsimile{{cite web|last1=L'Enfant|first1=Peter Charles|last2=[[Library of Congress]]|url=http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3850.ct001333|title=Plan of the city intended for the permanent seat of the government of t[he] United States: projected agreeable to the direction of the President of the United States, in pursuance of an act of Congress, passed on the sixteenth day of July, MDCCXC, "establishing the permanent seat on the bank of the Potowmac"|location=Washington, D.C.|publisher=Library of Congress|year=1991|lccn=91684074|accessdate=2017-03-05|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050301192926/http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3850.ct001333|archivedate=2005-03-01|df=}} Full-color [[facsimile]] of Peter Charles L'Enfant's 1791 manuscript plan for the City of Washington. ''In'' Repository of the [[Library of Congress]] Geography and Map Division, Washington, D.C. and an uncolored computer-assisted reproduction of that map. The manuscript's upper left corner contains an oval that identifies the title of the map, followed by the words "By Peter Charles L'Enfant" written in a block script that has the same alignment as does that in the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey's 1887 tracing.{{cite web|last1=L'Enfant|first1=Peter Charles|last2=[[Library of Congress]]|url=http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3850.ct000091|title=Plan of the city intended for the permanent seat of the government of t[he] United States: projected agreeable to the direction of the President of the United States, in pursuance of an act of Congress, passed on the sixteenth day of July, MDCCXC, "establishing the permanent seat on the bank of the Potowmac"|work=Facsimile: Computer-assisted reproduction of Pierre Charles L'Enfant's 1791 manuscript plan for the city of Washington, produced by the U.S. Geological Survey for the Library of Congress|location=Washington, D.C.|publisher=Library of Congress|year=1991|lccn=97683585|accessdate=2017-03-05|quote=Published by the Library of Congress in 1991 with support from the National Geographic Society, the U.S. Geological Survey, and the National Park Service.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050301192938/http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3850.ct000091|archivedate=2005-03-01|df=}} ''In'' Repository of the [[Library of Congress]] Geography and Map Division, Washington, D.C. The Library states that these reproductions were the Library's first facsimiles to be based on photography and electronic enhancement technology. The Library further states that, during the reproduction process, it was possible to record faint editorial annotations that Thomas Jefferson had made and which are now virtually illegible on the original map. The Library states (as did Partridge)[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468;view=1up;seq=33;size=125 Partridge, p. 25] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170408185722/https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112106620468 |date=2017-04-08 }} that it is believed that its Plan is one that L'Enfant submitted to President Washington in August 1791. However, others have contended that the named manuscript map that the Library holds is actually an earlier draft that was hand-delivered to George Washington in June 1791.{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170205200711/http://dcsymbols.com/chronology/maps.htm|archivedate=2017-02-05|url=http://dcsymbols.com/chronology/maps.htm |title=A Washington DC Map Chronology|publisher=dcsymbols.com|accessdate=2017-03-27}} The Library has in its collections a "Dotted line map of Washington, D.C., 1791" that lacks an author's name.{{cite web |last=L'Enfant|first=Peter Charles|url=http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3851b.ct000301|title=L'Enfant's ''Dotted line map of Washington, D.C., 1791'', before Aug. 19th |publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|year=1791|lccn=88694203|accessdate=2017-03-05|quote=Accompanied by positive and negative photocopies of L'Enfant's letter to George Washington, Aug. 19, 1791, the original in the L'Enfant papers, no. 0215-977, L.C. Ms. Div.}} ''In'': Repository of the [[Library of Congress]] Geography and Map Division Washington, D.C. The Library's notes state that this document is a "Ms. survey map drawn by P.C. L'Enfant" and is "accompanied by positive and negative photocopies of L'Enfant's letter to George Washington, Aug. 19, 1791, the original in the L'Enfant papers". (L'Enfant's papers include an August 19, 1791, letter to President Washington that contains an "annexed map of dotted lines".) The named plan would therefore be the one that L'Enfant annexed to his June 22, 1791 letter to the President. Comparisons of Andrew Ellicott's February 1792 revision of L'Enfant's Plan with the two manuscript maps suggest that Ellicott had based his revision (which printers distributed soon after its preparation) on the August 1791 "dotted line map", rather than on June 1791 manuscript. The L'Enfant Plan is depicted in [[Edward Savage (artist)|Edward Savage]]'s 1789–1796 painting, ''[[The Washington Family]]''. ==L'Enfant Plan in Freedom Plaza== [[File:Federal Plaza, Washington, DC.jpg|300px|right|thumb|Depiction of the L'Enfant Plan in [[Freedom Plaza]] (2006)]] [[File:Explanatory text.JPG|300px|right|thumb|Image of oval inscribed in [[Freedom Plaza]] containing the title of the L'Enfant Plan, followed by the words "By Peter Charles L'Enfant" in block script. (2006)]] In 1980, the Pennsylvania Avenue Development Corporation constructed Western Plaza along Pennsylvania Avenue in [[Northwest, Washington, D.C.|Northwest Washington, D.C.]] Designed by [[architect]] [[Robert Venturi]] and renamed in 1988 to [[Freedom Plaza]], the plaza contains an inlay that partially depicts the L'Enfant Plan.(1) {{cite web|last=Cooper|first=Rachel|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170126143520/http://dc.about.com/od/dcparks/a/FreedomPlaza.htm|archivedate=2017-01-26|title=Freedom Plaza in Washington, DC|accessdate=2017-03-27|work=About.com: About Travel: Washington, DC: Sports & Recreation: Parks and Recreation: DC Parks|publisher=About, Inc.|year=2017|url=http://dc.about.com/od/dcparks/a/FreedomPlaza.htm}}
(2) {{cite web|url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=17966|publisher=Historical Marker Database|accessdate=2011-03-21|date=2009-04-13|author=Miller, Richard E.|title=Western Plaza, Pennsylvania Avenue (Freedom Plaza) Marker|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111019121503/http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=17966|archivedate=2011-10-19|df=}}
(3) {{cite web|url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=17943|publisher=Historical Marker Database|accessdate=2011-03-21|date=2009-04-14|author=Miller, Richard E.|title=Freedom Plaza: Civil War to Civil Rights: Downtown Heritage Trail marker}}
(4) {{cite web|last1=Busch|first1=Richard T.|last2=Smith|first2=Kathryn Schneider|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160321163221/http://www.culturaltourismdc.org/portal/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=c0f25a0f-cefa-48a3-969d-782904380b40&groupId=701982|archivedate=2016-03-21|url=http://www.culturaltourismdc.org/portal/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=c0f25a0f-cefa-48a3-969d-782904380b40&groupId=701982|work=Civil War to Civil Rights Downtown Heritage Trail|title=W.7: Freedom Plaza: 13th and E Sts NW|place=Washington, DC|publisher=Cultural Tourism DC|accessdate=2017-03-27}} The last line in an oval inscribed in the Plaza contains the words "By Peter Charles L'Enfant" in a block script.Coordinates of inscription of L'Enfant's name in Freedom Plaza: {{coord|38.895838|-77.031254|type:landmark|name=Inscription of name of "Peter Charles L'Enfant" in inlay of L'Enfant's plan in Freedom Plaza|format=dms}} ==List of contributing parks== *Reservation 1 [[President's Park]] *Reservation 2–6 [[National Mall]]; [[United States Capitol#Grounds|U.S. Capitol Grounds]] *Reservation 7 [[Judiciary Square]] *Reservation 8 [[Mount Vernon Square]] *Reservation 9 [[Franklin Square (Washington, D.C.)|Franklin Square]] *Reservation 10 [[President's Park#Lafayette Square|Lafayette Square]] *Reservation 11 [[McPherson Square]] *Reservation 12 [[Farragut Square]] *Reservation 13 [[General John A. [[Image:Dictionarium trium lingvarum.jpg|171 px|thumb|First Lithuanian language dictionary]] '''Lithuanian dictionaries''', i.e., [[dictionaries]] of [[Lithuanian language]] have been printed since the first half of the 17th century.
==History== The first [[Lithuanian language]] dictionary was compiled by [[Konstantinas Sirvydas]] and printed in 1629 as a trilingual (Polish–Latin–Lithuanian) dictionary. Five editions of it were printed until 1713, but it was used and copied by other lexicographers until the 19th century.<ref name=LIT>[http://www.lituanus.org/1981_4/81_4_01.htm "Kazimieras Būga and the Academic Dictionary of Lithuanian"], by [[:lt:Antanas Klimas|Antanas Klimas]], ''[[Lituanus]]'', vol. 27, no.4, 1981</ref><ref name=EL>[http://www.spaudos.lt/LietKalba/Dictionaries.en.htm "Dictionaries" article from ''[[Encyclopedia Lituanica]]''], based on the article from ''Lituanus''</ref>
The first German–Lithuanian–German dictionary, to address the necessities of [[Lithuania Minor]] was published by Friedrich W. Haack in 1730.<ref name=LIT/> A better German–Lithuanian–German dictionary, with a sketch of grammar and history of the language, more words, and systematic orthography, was published by [[Philipp Ruhig]] in 1747.<ref name=LIT/> In 1800, {{ill|Christian Gottlieb Mielcke|lt|Kristijonas Gotlybas Milkus}} printed an expanded and revised version of Ruhig's dictionary. Its foreword was the last work of [[Immanuel Kant]] printed during his life.<ref>[http://www.unesco.org/webworld/mdm/visite/vilnius/knygos/fondas/milke/anglu/emmilke.htm Mielcke's Lithuanian dictionary]</ref>
There also existed a number of notable unpublished dictionaries.
At the beginning of the 19th century linguists recognized the preserved archaic character of Lithuanian, and it came into the focus of the [[comparative linguistics]] of [[Indo-European languages]]. To address the needs of linguists, [[Georg H. F. Nesselmann]] published a Lithuanian–German dictionary in 1851.<ref name=LIT/>
The culmination of Lithuanian linguists' efforts is the 20-volume ''[[Academic Dictionary of Lithuanian]]''.<ref name=EL/>

{{about|documentation relating to a medical examination|certification to perform medical procedures|medical credentials|the television series Sick Note|Sick Note (TV series)}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Medcirc.PNG|thumb|Sample FAA [[airman]] medical certificate.]] -->
A '''medical certificate''' or '''doctor's certificate'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.workplaceinfo.com.au/payroll/leave/employers-should-not-question-doctors-certificates-ama |title=Employers should not question a doctor’s certificate: AMA |publisher=Workplaceinfo.com.au |date=2014-12-01 |access-date=2014-12-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medicalobserver.com.au/news/doctors-certificate-questioned-after-mp-skips-parliament |title=Doctor’s certificate questioned after MP skips parliament |publisher=Medical Observer |date=2012-03-19 |access-date=2013-01-10}}</ref> is a written statement from a [[physician]] or other medically qualified [[health care provider]] which attests to the result of a [[physical examination|medical examination]] of a patient.<ref name="Ashtekar2001">{{cite book|author=S. Ashtekar|title=Health and Healing: A Manual of Primary Health Care|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F0wYJXsHBIAC&pg=PA576|access-date=10 January 2013|date=1 January 2001|publisher=Orient Blackswan|isbn=978-81-250-1624-3|pages=576–}}</ref> It can serve as a "sick note" (documentation that an employee is unfit for work) or evidence of a health condition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.workplaceinfo.com.au/payroll/payroll-management/medical-certificates |title=Medical certificates |publisher=Workplaceinfo.com.au |date= |access-date=2013-01-10}}</ref>
An '''aegrotat''' ({{IPAc-en|'|iː|g|r|oʊ|t|æ|t|}}; {{etymology|la|aegrotat|he/she is ill}})<ref> {{cite book | last = Mohammad | first = Hassan | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Shail Medical and Maitarniti Centre | year = 2016 | location = Daira Dubai }}</ref> or '''sick note''' is a type of medical certificate excusing a student's absence from school for reasons of [[illness]].
==Purpose and applications== Medical certificates are sometimes required to obtain certain [[Health insurance|health benefits]] from an employer, to make an insurance [[Cause of action|claim]], for tax purposes, or for certain legal procedures. Medical certificates are used to indicate eligibility of activity, such as the use of [[Disabled parking permit|disabled parking]]. Medical certificates can also be used to describe a medical condition a person has, such as blindness. Medical certificates are often used to certify that someone is free of [[Infection|contagious diseases]], [[Substance dependence|drug addiction]], [[Mental disorder|mental illness]], or other health issues.
Health criteria are often required when making an application for something, such as an [[eye examination]] to get a driver's license. Other times medical criteria are presented voluntarily by an applicant in a self-assessment, without either a doctor or access to the person's [[medical record]]. Specific health criteria or medical history are required for certain jobs.
In the United States, most [[Aircraft pilot|aviators]] are required to possess a valid medical certificate that certifies sound health as part of the requirements for piloting an [[airplane]] or [[helicopter]].<ref name="Pilot'sHandbook">{{cite book |title=Pilot's Handbook of Aeronautical Knowledge |last=U.S. Department of Transportation, Federal Aviation Administration |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2009 |publisher=Government Printing Office |location= |isbn=0160823676 |page=16-2 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=0l8WO6Drz50C&pg=SA16-PA2&dq=medical+certificate#v=onepage&q=medical%20certificate&f=false |access-date=February 7, 2017}}</ref> While airman certificates are issued for life, the medical certificate expires and must be renewed periodically in order continue flying privileges. [[Pilot certification in the United States#Sport pilot|Sport pilots]] may use a valid state driver's license in place of a medical certificate, and [[Glider (aircraft)|glider]] and [[hot air balloon]] pilots are not required to obtain them.<ref name="Pilot'sHandbook" />
==Aegrotat== The term ''aegrotat'' (abbreviated as ''aegrot'') is used primarily in the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Commonwealth of Nations]]. In the context of [[British undergraduate degree classification|British undergraduate degrees]] a student who is too ill to finish may be awarded an aegrotat degree if the student otherwise would have passed exams or other requirements.<ref>[http://www.vuw.ac.nz/st_services/counselling/appointments/aegrotat-info.aspx A New Zealand university policy on aegrotat degrees]</ref>
==Impact on occupation== Except in certain unique circumstances, a holder of a medical certificate in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration may not "act as pilot in command or in any other capacity as a required flight crewmember of an aircraft".<ref>{{Cite journal | url = https://books.google.com/?id=7cg5AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA148&dq=%22medical+certificate%22#v=onepage&q=%22medical%20certificate%22&f=false | title = The Code of Federal Regulations of the United States of America | author1 = Staff | first1 = National Aeronautics and Space Administration | pages = 12 | year = 1982}}</ref>
A patient with conditions such as: measles, chicken-pox, hepatitis A, leprosy, typhoid fever, and whooping cough, can return to work immediately after their healing phase or medical tests. Almost always the patient may only be allowed to return to work upon submission of a medical certificate.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M1HOA3sCXNkC&pg=PA487&dq=%22medical+certificate%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1sHvUOWGA4aiiAel5oCgCw&ved=0CEgQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=%22medical%20certificate%22&f=false | title=Manual Of Community Nursing and Communicable Diseases | accessdate=January 11, 2013 | pages=487}}</ref>
==Eligibility== Sometimes, there are standards and procedures in place, for workers in a certain field to be eligible to receive a medical certificate. Any airman at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration must give their employees access to the National Driver Register. On top of this, other tests which are required for first-, second- and third-class airmen are: eye, ear/nose/throat/equilibrium, mental, neurologic, and cardiovascular.<ref>{{Cite journal | url = https://books.google.com/?id=7cg5AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA148&dq=%22medical+certificate%22#v=onepage&q=%22medical%20certificate%22&f=false | title = The Code of Federal Regulations of the United States of America | author1 = Staff | first1 = National Aeronautics and Space Administration | pages = 67 | year = 1982}}</ref>
''The India List and India Office List 1905'' explains that officers on "Long Leave in Europe" must, among other things, provide a medical certificate, which is obtained at the Medical Board of India Office.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3VQTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA262&dq=%22medical+certificate%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=o8HvUK_2GpDBiQfyr4GIDA&ved=0CGMQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22medical%20certificate%22&f=false | title=The India List and India Office List | accessdate=January 11, 2013 | pages=262}}</ref>
''Practical Guide to Employees' State Insurance Act, Rules and Regulations'' explains that under the ESI Act, the employee must obtain a medical certificate via the ESI Dispensary/Hospital, which then gets deposited at the nearest office of the ESI Corporation.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=couYMu1aa5oC&pg=PA275&dq=%22medical+certificate%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=o8HvUK_2GpDBiQfyr4GIDA&ved=0CGgQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%22medical%20certificate%22&f=false | title=Practical Guide to Employees' State Insurance Act, Rules and Regulations | accessdate=January 11, 2013 | pages=126}}</ref>
==Falsification== As many illnesses can come about suddenly, sometimes the worker will not have enough time to receive a medical certificate, or may be too sick to obtain one. In other cases, the worker may not be bothered to go to the trouble of getting one, or may be lying about their illness and want to falsify a certificate to back up their story to their boss.
There have been discussions regarding whether it is okay to fire someone for submitting a fabricated medical certificates.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mk.com.au/publications/article/sacked-for-submitting-false-medical-certificates-fair | title=Sacked for Submitting False Medical Certificates - Fair? | accessdate=January 11, 2013}}</ref> In many cases, it is deemed wrong, such as in Australia where a bank officer was dismissed after handing in a forged certificate, which prompted a Fair Work Australia Commissioner to say they had a "continued lack of regard for the truth".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://blog.vecci.org.au/2012/02/16/employee-sacked-for-creating-false-medical-certificate/ | title=Employee sacked for creating false medical certificate | accessdate=January 11, 2013}}</ref> Another example is a WA police officer who was stood down after committing the same offense.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/officer-stood-down-for-allegedly-forging-medical-certificate-20081218-713y.html | title=Officer stood down for allegedly forging medical certificate| date=December 18, 2008 | accessdate=January 11, 2013}}</ref> Sometimes it is not so black and white. In one case, a woman claimed she was "coerced into falsifying [a] medical certificate [which ultimately led to her being fired] because she was 'being bullied and treated unfairly' by two managers".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://aworkcovervictimsdiary.com/2012/09/sacked-worker-forged-medical-certificate-claimed-nearly-died-way-treated/ | title=Sacked worker forged medical certificate and claimed she nearly died because the way she was treated | accessdate=January 11, 2013}}</ref>
There are some companies that sell fake medical certificates. Although the site ''Doctors Note Store'' sells "fake sick notes and medical certificates for workers in Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom", they add that the "fakes are for 'novelty use only'".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.workplaceinfo.com.au/payroll/leave/ama-warns-over-fake-sick-notes | title=AMA warns over fake sick notes | accessdate=January 11, 2013}}</ref>
At Flinders University, "providing a forged medical certificate" is viewed as academic misconduct.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.flinders.edu.au/current-students/policies-procs/rights/important-changes.cfm | title=Important Changes to the University’s Student Policies and Procedures | accessdate=January 11, 2013}}</ref>
In New South Wales, medical professionals who "deliberately issue a false, misleading or inaccurate certificate" can be charged under the Medical Practice Act. This is in response to The New South Wales Medical Board "receiving numerous complaints from employers, insurers, the courts, etc regarding the quality, accuracy and truthfulness of sickness certificates".<ref name="MCP">{{cite web | url=http://www.mcnsw.org.au/page/old-policies/medical-certificates-policy/ | title=Medical Certificates Policy | page = 67 |accessdate=January 11, 2013}}</ref>
==Validation== In order to prove that one's medical certificate is authentic, the following should be done and taken into consideration:<ref name="MCP"/>
* Having it written in legible text, in the doctor's handwriting, and without "abbreviations or medical jargon". * Should only include facts or observations made by the doctor, and each should be justified. * Should include the date of appointment, how sick the patient is, the date they can go back to work, be addressed to the recipient of the certificate (boss etc.), * Should only be for something "observed by the doctor" or "reported by the patient and deemed to be true by the doctor". * Can be issued after the patient has taken sick leave, but it must include the date of appointment, and the length of time the employee should be out of work for. * Should consider if the patient can return to work before they have fully healed, but with "altered duties". * Respect "rights to confidentiality" and consent of patient (sometimes, the reason for sick leave may be personal and the patient may request it taken off the certificate, in which case "it should be made clear to the patient that the information provided on the certificate may not be sufficient to attract sick leave and that an employer has the ultimate right to accept or to reject a certificate". * Falsifying a medical certificate is a form of fraud.
